column2: P5JS - Making it interactive!
What you'll do
Take your P5JS knowledge to the next level by making it interactive. (Part 2)
Hi there! I'm glad you're back, {{user_name}} - I've got something awesome to show you!

First things first - let's get back to the p5.js code editor. You can load your previous sketch (if you saved it at http://editor.p5js.org ), or get back to where we left off with this one: https://editor.p5js.org/madetohack/sketches/4Ko8JXYN
Last time we made the background prettier using the code background('green') or background('#76EECF'), and then we drew a circle on top of it.
The circle code was circle(100,200,50) giving it an X-coordinate of 100, a Y-coordinate of 200, and a diameter of 50.
In order to make the circle a color other than white, we have to use a command called fill()
Go ahead and make a new line of code before the circle() command that says fill('blue'); and run the code by clicking play (or auto-refresh).
Ah, that's better. But what about that annoying black line around the outside?
That's called the stroke, and we can get rid of it by typing strokeWeight(0); on a new line.
Of course, we could also make it thicker by typing strokeWeight(10) instead - the number in parentheses is how many pixels wide you want it.
And we can even change the color of the outline - try stroke('red'); or stroke('#E84904');
Once you have your circle looking like you want it, let's take another look at our code that draws the circle: circle(100,200,50)
Remember how I said the first number in parentheses was the X-coordinate? X means side-to-side, or how far left or right the circle is.
What if instead of drawing that circle at X-coordinate 100 every time, we drew the circle at the X-coordinate of my cursor?
To do this, replace the number 100 with mouseX and run the program.
You should have circle(mouseX, 200, 50); and if you move your mouse back and forth along the canvas, you should see it following along left to right!
Notice that the circle is not moving up and down, because its Y-coordinate is still 200 every time. But we can change that, too!
If you type circle(mouseX, mouseY, 50);, you can make the circle follow your mouse exactly throughout the canvas!
Wheeeeee! Sorry, I'm having too much fun...
I have more to show you, but before we go too much farther, let's learn how to save our work.
At the top of the screen, there is a File menu. Click on it, and you will find the option to Save.
Note that in order to save your work, you have to sign up with an email address and make an account.
If you don't have an email address or you're not allowed to sign up, no worries! Just copy and paste your code somewhere for safekeeping.
Once your code is saved, you can close your computer, go stretch your legs, and come back when you're ready to learn the next steps!
